120466 120466 S0926-860X(25)00367-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120466 The Authors Fig. 1 Schematic representation of a DLP printer [15] (a) and a printing example: from CAD design to the final γ-Al2O3 structured body (b). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Representation of the loop reactor (a) and schematic view of the tank-in-series model (b). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Palladium deposition results with different wet methods: PdCl2 (top) and Pd(Ac)2 (bottom). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Particle size distributions of the different Pd/Al2O3 catalysts determined by TEM. (a) Pd(Cl)H (b) Pd(Ac)H (c) Pd(Ac)B (d) Pd(Ac)HB (e) Pd(Ac)HSB. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Summary of the kinetic experiments for palladium catalysts prepared with PdCl2 method. a) Pd(Cl)O b) Pd(Cl)H. The reaction temperature was 60 °C. Scattered points represent the experimental data, while continuous lines represent the simulation results. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Summary of the kinetic experiments for Pd/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with PdAc2 method and reduced under hydrogen atmosphere at different temperatures: a) 20°C b) 40 °C c) 60°C. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Regeneration experiments on Pd(Ac)H catalyst: regeneration a) in H2 atmosphere and b) with NaBH4. The experiment was repeated three times to monitor the catalyst durability. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Activity profiles for Pd(Ac)B (a) and Pd(Ac)HB catalysts (b). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Parity plot comprising all the experiments for batch (a) and tank-in-series models (b). Simulated and experimental data are expressed in terms of hydrogen peroxide conversion level. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Summary of XPS analysis for catalyst prepared with a) Pd(Cl)2 method and b) Pd(Ac)2 method. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Comparison of TPR profiles for fresh and spent catalysts. Naples Industrial Chemistry Laboratory (NICL), University of Naples Federico II Napoli 80126 Italy Design, fabrication, and evaluation of the performance of 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ catalysts for the low-temperature catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide was investigated. Catalyst supports were manufactured using a digital light processing (DLP) 3D printing technique, followed by post-printing infiltration with colloidal boehmite to enhance the mechanical strength of the supports. Wet impregnation methods using PdCl₂ and Pd(Ac)₂ as the palladium precursors were employed to deposit metal nanoparticles onto the structured alumina supports. For the most effective deposition route, various strategies, using either molecular hydrogen or sodium borohydride as the reducing agent, were applied to assess their influence on the catalytic activity. The decomposition experiments were carried out in a closed-loop batch reactor system. Apparent rate constants and deactivation coefficients were estimated using simplified batch and tank-in-series reactor models. Catalyst durability was further investigated with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to assess the oxidation states of the palladium nanoparticle surface, and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) to evaluate the reducibility of the palladium oxides. Structure–activity relationships were established by correlating kinetic parameters with hydrogen uptake data and average nanoparticle size obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The results demonstrated the critical impact of the precursor and the reduction methods on both the initial activity and the resistance against deactivation. This work provides a robust foundation for the further development of 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ catalysts, offering a promising pathway to improve the efficiency of green propulsion systems for small satellites utilizing hydrogen peroxide as a propellant. The core concept behind AM is the decomposition of any structure into a series of very thin layers, enabling the construction of three-dimensional objects in a layer-by-layer fashion [2]. One of the most significant advantages of 3D printing lies in its capacity for rapid prototyping. In the field of chemical engineering, 3D printing is revolutionizing the efficiency of existing chemical processes and unit operations enabling the production of new designs for heat exchangers [3], chemical reactors [4,5], and advanced internal components for continuous reactors [6,7]. One of the key areas where 3D printing has a huge potential in chemical engineering is catalyst shaping [8]. The motivation for introducing structured catalysts and reactors arises from fundamental design considerations of catalytic processes. According to Krishna and Sie [9], optimizing the reactor performance involves navigating a complex landscape of interdependent parameters such as catalytic kinetics, heat and mass transfer effects and pressure drop. In conventional packed bed reactors, design constraints often force trade-offs. Large catalyst particles are required to control the pressure drop, compromising the reaction efficiency due to fluid maldistribution in the bed and increased impact of the intraparticle diffusion resistance. Novel structured catalysts, such as monoliths, fibers, solid foams, and 3D-printed structures enable the decoupling of mass transport phenomena and pressure drop by independently tuning the hydrodynamic diameters, which primarily influence the pressure drop, and the thickness of the catalyst layer, which affects the diffusional length and the catalyst effectiveness factor [10]. With additive manufacturing, it is possible to move beyond traditional honeycomb monolithic structures and completely new structures can be designed with periodic architectures that can improve the flow pattern and provide a high local turbulence compared to the pure laminar flow in monoliths with straight channels [11]. To date, Direct Ink Writing (DIW) has been extensively applied to 3D print catalyst materials with enhanced geometrical complexity compared to classical catalyst extrudates [12]. In DIW, a ceramic paste containing the catalytic materials and additives is extruded through needles along digitally defined pathways to print the layers of the 3D structure. Recently, Digital Light Processing (DLP) 3D printing has appeared as a promising technology due to excellent resolution and high printing speed [13]. DLP 3D printers employ a UV-light source to ensure selective polymerization of photoactive polymers. A schematic representation of a DLP printer is shown in Fig. 1a. A liquid photopolymer is placed in a vat with a transparent film on the bottom, ensuring a high transmission of UV light. The structures are created on the surface of a built platform in a bottom-up approach. DLP 3D printed catalytic materials are obtained by mixing small catalyst particles (< 50 μm) with the components of a photocurable resin. In the resulting print, known as the green body (GB), the catalyst particles coexist with the organic polymer. Heat treatment is applied to remove the organic components from the body [14]. In case of alumina catalyst structures, infiltration of colloidal nanoparticles has been recently proposed by our research group to improve the strength of the structured bodies while preserving the specific surface area, obtaining shaped bodies with unprecedented resolution (Fig. 1b) [15]. Many important chemical processes, such as oxidations and hydrogenations, rely on nanodispersed metals (e.g., Pt, Pd, Au, Zn) as heterogeneous catalysts. Consequently, the efficient deposition of active metal nanoparticles onto the surface of catalytic supports is of high importance. Typically, metal nanoparticles are introduced into porous systems by contacting the support material with a metal salt precursor. In dry impregnation, i.e. incipient wetness methods, the precursor is dissolved in a volume of solvent equal to the pore volume of the support [16]. This technique allows for complete deposition efficiency, but controlling the size and the distribution of nanoparticles remains challenging. In contrast, wet impregnation methods use an excess of solvent, and the interaction between the precursor and the support is influenced by factors such as the solvent type, isoelectric point of the support, precursor characteristics, and the pH of the solution [17]. Although some wet methods, such as adsorption and ion exchange provide a better control over metal nanoparticle size on the nanoscale, they do not always ensure a complete metal deposition onto the support material [18]. An exception is given by evaporation-impregnation methods, where the solvent is evaporated to ensure complete metal deposition. However, poor control on the nanoparticle size is obtained with this method. Structured catalysts and reactors provide a great opportunity for the intensification of chemical processes that are operated in the regime of mass transfer control and in fluid-dynamic regimes far from the ideal plug flow pattern, with a high impact of axial dispersion effects and back-mixing phenomena. Complex physical structures have not shown any significant improvement in the performance of chemical processes operating in the regime of intrinsic kinetics [19]. Indeed, the catalyst shaping techniques control the catalyst morphology at the macroscale, without altering molecular catalytic mechanism occurring at the nanoscale [20] For rapid reactions e.g., methane oxidation, significant improvement in terms of space-time yields have been observed [21]. Therefore, huge potential of 3D printed structured materials is foreseen in the aerospace sector, particularly for propulsion systems relying on green propellants such as hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) [22], which decomposes at high temperatures to form gaseous oxygen and water, H2O2 → 0.5 O2 + H2O The reaction is highly exothermic (ΔH = −98 kJ mol−1) and the total number of moles increases because of the chemical reaction, causing an expansion of the reaction mixture as gaseous oxygen is formed. In the context of aerospace research, hydrogen peroxide is employed in both monopropellant [23] and hybrid rockets [24]. Although hydrogen peroxide decomposes thermally, the application of heterogeneous catalysts e.g., MnO2, supported Pt and Pd catalysts lower significantly the required temperature of the thruster chambers [25]. Since the catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide is typically a rapid process, diffusional limitations and concentration gradients within the catalyst pellets are likely to appear. Additionally, catalyst deactivation has emerged as a major concern in propulsion experiments, since the catalytic activity can be fully extinguished after a single experiment [26,27]. Although catalytic hydrogen peroxide decomposition takes place at 600 °C in typical thrusters, the low-temperature activity toward hydrogen peroxide decomposition is also of high relevance in propulsion systems. Indeed, the heat released from the chemical reaction can be applied to warm up the catalytic chamber, avoiding the utilization of an external heat source. Moreover, it is crucial to ensure a rapid response from the catalytic system to enable prompt engine ignition. Several studies have been conducted on its reactivity prior to reaching steady-state conditions (in the case of monopropellant systems [28]) or flame ignition (in hybrid systems [29]). Catalysts exhibiting a high hydrogen peroxide decomposition activity at low temperatures are of outmost interest to improve the efficiency of conventional thrusters for small satellites. The design of catalysts via 3D printing should aim to produce structures capable of maximizing exposed surface area per unit of reactor volume, minimizing the required catalyst mass and reducing the pressure drops in the engine. Therefore, this study proposes methods for fabricating 3D printed Pd/Al2O3 catalyst architectures, with a huge potential for the intensification of existing propulsion engines which are currently operated with Pd/Al2O3 tablets [25]. Nonetheless, the technology developed in this work is not limited to the aerospace sector. On the contrary, it can be easily transferred to other chemical processes in which Pd catalysts are the key catalytic materials e.g., oxidation and reduction of important molecules derived from biomass. Herein, Structured alumina bodies were manufactured via Digital Light Processing (DLP) printing technology. Different wet deposition techniques were employed to deposit palladium nanoparticles on the alumina support, using palladium chloride Pd(Cl)2 and palladium acetate Pd(Ac)2 as the palladium precursors. For the most promising approach, different reduction methods, either using gaseous hydrogen or sodium borohydride (NaBH4) in the liquid phase as reducing agents, were applied. The catalyst structures were loaded in a glass jacketed-tubular reactor and hydrogen peroxide decomposition experiments were carried out under isothermal conditions in a closed loop reactor system. The experiments were conducted at low temperature, ensuring safe operation processes in the laboratory scale equipment. The kinetic experiments were described with batch and tank-in-series models to estimate apparent rate constants and deactivation parameters. Catalyst characterization (TPR, XPS and TEM) was carried out to investigate the principal cause of the catalyst deactivation, and the impact of the reduction method on the activity and stability of the catalysts was established. 2 Experiments, methods and mathematical approaches 2.1 Materials and DLP 3D printer specifications The components of the ceramic ink to DLP 3D print γ-Al2O3 were poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA, Mn = 250 g/mol, Sigma Aldrich) as the reactive oligomer, Sudan III (Sigma Aldrich) to modulate the UV absorption and the photoinitiator bis(2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyl)-phenylphosphine oxide (IRGACURE 819, Sigma Aldrich). 1-propanol was selected as a non-reactive diluent. The commercial γ-Al2O3 Versal GH22 (Honeywell UOP) and the water dispersible boehmite DISPERAL P2 (Sasol) were employed as solid components in the liquid ink. Span 80 (sorbitan monooleate, Sigma Aldrich) was chosen as the dispersing agent. The catalyst structures were fabricated using a B9Creations DLP printer, featuring a build platform measuring 96 × 54 mm and a maximum build height of 127 mm. The printer utilized an industrial high-resolution UV LED light engine operating at the wavelength of 405 nm. During the printing process, each layer was set to a thickness of 40 μm with an exposure time of 6 s. To ensure a strong adhesion to the build platform, the initial six layers were exposed to UV light for 30 s. The digital models were designed using nTop 4.0 software, and the corresponding STL files were processed into layers using B9Create 2.0 software. For the palladium deposition, palladium chloride (99 % PdCl2, Sigma Aldrich) and palladium acetate (99 % Pd(Ac)2, Sigma Aldrich) were employed as palladium precursors. Distilled water and acetone (VWR) were used as the solvents to dissolve the palladium salts. 2.2 Additive manufacturing of the alumina catalyst architectures The preparation of the 3D printed catalyst supports was carried out according to the procedure reported in our previous work [15]. The boehmite DISPERAL P2 and alumina VERSAL GH22 powders were dried at 110°C for 6 h in an oven to remove the excess of moisture. The solid materials were transferred in a mixer mill (MM500, Retsch) with 12 stainless steel balls of 1.5 cm in diameter with an alumina-to-boehmite weight ratio 4:1, where they were mixed and milled for 15 h at 7 Hz. Subsequently, PEDGA, 1-propanol, Span 80 and SUDAN III were added, and the milling frequency decreased at 5 Hz. The components were mixed in the mill for 20 min. Finally, IRGACURE 819 was added and dissolved in the ceramic resin mixing it at 3 Hz for two minutes. The addition of the photoinitiator was intentionally left at the end of the mixing process as premature resin polymerization was observed in the mixer mill at higher milling frequencies and prolonged times. The amounts and weight fractions of the ceramic resin components are listed in Table 1. The printed structures (Green body, GB) were immersed in ethanol for ten minutes to remove any excess of uncured liquid from the bodies. Subsequently, overcuring was performed in a B9 XL curing unit (B9 Creations), exposing the GBs to UV light for 5 min at 35 W cm−2 and 10 min at 70 W cm−2. The samples were dried overnight at 110 °C to eliminate residual volatile components such as ethanol and propanol and calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. The heating rate was kept very low (0.2 °C/min) in the region where most of the mass loss occurred (20–400 °C) but increased at 1 °C min−1 to complete the removal of organic components. The thermogravimetric analysis dictating the thermolysis program is reported in our previous work [15]. Infiltration of a 5 wt% colloidal suspension of boehmite DISPERAL P2 in water was employed to improve the strength of the alumina structured bodies. The structures were dried at room temperature for 3 h and finally calcined at 750 °C to convert the boehmite nanoparticles into alumina. The infiltration-calcination process was repeated two times to improve the strength of the shaped bodies. The CAD files for 3D printing were prepared with the nTop 4.0 software. For the catalytic experiments, a periodic monolithic structure was prepared repeating a 3 × 3 mm gyroid unit cell in the three-dimensional space. The dimensions of the cylindrical monolith were 14.6 × 10 mm (d x h), which were carefully designed to fit the reactor tube after shrinking because the organic components degraded from the green body. The wall thickness was set at 500 μm. Smaller structures of 5 × 5 mm were printed using the same procedure for the characterization purposes. 2.3 Deposition of palladium on the 3D printed alumina structures Prior to the palladium deposition, the alumina catalyst architectures were dried overnight at 110 °C. Two deposition protocols were applied depending on the type of palladium precursor. In both cases, the goal was to achieve a total palladium loading of 2 wt%. 2.3.1 Deposition with palladium chloride The required mass of PdCl2 precursor was pre-dissolved in a 5 mL vial in distilled water and 40–50 μL of 30 % HCl to form the complex [PdCl4]2-. Ultrasonication was applied to enhance the palladium salt dissolution. The solution was transferred in a glass flask and diluted in 150 mL of distilled water. The obtained solution had pH= 3. The flask was kept in rotation in an oil bath with a set temperature of 70 °C. As the liquid reached the desired temperature, the catalyst structures were immersed in the liquid solution for 4 h to favour the electrostatic adsorption of [PdCl4]2- on the positively charged alumina surface. Subsequently, the catalyst structures were washed to remove the excess of chlorine and calcined at 750 °C for 3 h. 2.3.2 Deposition of palladium acetate The required amount of palladium acetate Pd(Ac)2 was dissolved in 10 mL of acetone, and it was transferred to a graduated cylinder. The alumina structures were immersed in the liquid to contact the palladium acetate species with the alumina surface at room temperature. The progress of the deposition was monitored visually observing the change in color of the precursor solution, highlighting the transfer of the palladium from the solution to the solid catalyst. Once the deposition was completed, the structures were dried at room temperature and calcined at 750 °C for 3 h. 2.3.3 Reduction methods The importance of the oxidation state of the palladium nanoparticles was investigated on catalysts prepared from PdCl2 precursor. Given the critical influence of the oxidation state on both the catalytic activity and stability, the effect of different reducing agents was explored, using gaseous molecular hydrogen (H₂), sodium borohydride (NaBH₄), separately and in combination. Accordingly, a series of Pd/Al₂O₃ structured catalysts were prepared and evaluated in hydrogen peroxide decomposition experiments. To reveal the impact of deposition techniques, catalysts prepared from PdCl2 or Pd(Ac)2 were compared using the same reduction method. Different reduction strategies were examined using the most promising palladium precursor. The nomenclature used to describe the different catalyst preparation methods is summarized below: • PdO(Cl) – catalyst prepared from PdCl2 precursor, calcined at 750 °C and tested without further reduction. • Pd(Cl)H – prepared as PdO(Cl) and reduced under H2 flow at 350 °C for 3 h. • Pd(Ac)H – catalyst prepared from Pd(Ac)2 precursor, calcined at 750 °C and reduced under H2 flow at 350 °C for 3 h. • Pd(Ac)B – catalyst prepared from Pd(Ac)2 precursor, calcined at 750 °C and reduced at room temperature in a 50 mL NaBH4 solution (Pd/NaBH4 = 1:3). • Pd(Ac)HB - prepared as Pd(Ac)H and further treated at room temperature in a 50 mL NaBH4 solution (Pd/NaBH4 = 1:3). • Pd(Ac)HSB – prepared as Pd(Ac)H, used in reaction (S = spent) and further treated at room temperature in a 50 mL NaBH4 solution (Pd/NaBH4 = 1:3). 2.4 Characterization techniques Nitrogen physisorption (Micrometrics 3Flex-3500) was employed to determine the specific surface area and pore size distribution of the alumina catalyst support. For the measurements, cubic structures of approximately 5 × 5 mm in size were prepared to fit into the measurement tubes avoiding crushing the structures. The efficiency of the palladium deposition method was quantified by measuring the actual palladium content with ICP-OES measurements (PerkinElmer Optima 5300 DV instrument). The nanoparticle size and morphology were investigated with transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 1400 Plus). The analysis was conducted on both fresh and spent catalysts to check a possibility of nanoparticle sintering. The catalyst reducibility was investigated with temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments (Microtrac Belcat II, Bel-Japan Inc.). Prior to the experiment, the sample (ca. 100 mg) was dried at 200 °C for 2 h under 30 mL min−1 argon flow. Subsequently, the sample cell was cooled down at 30 °C and the flow was switched to 5 vol% hydrogen. A waiting time of 1 h was required to obtain stabilization of the thermal conductivity (TC) detector signal prior to the experiment. Afterwards, the temperature was increased up to 800°C at 10 °C min−1 and the hydrogen consumption was measured. At the end of the experiment, the equipment allowed the calibration of the signals to obtain quantitative information on the consumed hydrogen. Experiments were conducted on fresh and spent catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM/EDX, Leo Gemini 1530) was employed to examine the internal structure and elemental distribution within the catalyst walls. The oxidation state of palladium was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a NEXSA XPS (Thermo Fischer Scientific). Al Kα radiation was used for the measurements with a spot size of 400 µm. Peak fitting was done with XPSPeak4.1 software, prior to peak fitting the Shirley background was subtracted from the data. Adventitious carbon C1s peak was used as a reference peak to take possible sample charging into account. 2.5 Apparatus for kinetic investigations The hydrogen peroxide decomposition experiments were conducted in a tubular packed-bed reactor glass configured in a closed-loop system ( Fig. 2a). The configuration was designed to immobilize the catalyst structure in a tube and to ensure isothermal operation as the experiments were conducted at high flow rates and low residence times (380 mL min−1, τ = 0.1 s), leading to low conversion per pass. The packed bed reactor consisted of a column with an internal diameter of 1.3 cm and a height of 50 cm, equipped with a heating jacket for temperature control. The reactor outlet was coupled with a 500 mL jacketed mixing tank equipped with a Teflon stirrer to ensure homogeneous composition of the liquid in the tank. During the experiments, the stirring rate was kept constant at 400 rpm. The mixing tank was equipped with a condenser to avoid the removal of water vapours. The condenser was connected to the atmosphere to prevent accumulation of the produced oxygen from the loop system. Prior to the catalytic zone, the tube was filled with 3 mm glass beads to ensure uniform fluid distribution. The total volume of the loop was 53 mL (V1 + V2 + Vcat) when packed with glass spheres. The tested catalyst structures were positioned at 30 cm from the bottom of tube. The experiments were conducted using 150 mL of a 5 wt% hydrogen peroxide solution. Samples were periodically withdrawn to monitor the extent of the reaction. The hydrogen peroxide content was measured with cerimetric titration [30]. The reaction experiments were conducted by fixing the flow rate of the recycling pump at 380 mL min−1. Most of the reaction experiments were conducted at 20 °C. In case of palladium catalysts prepared with PdCl2, the experiments were conducted at 60 °C to enhance the conversion level also for catalysts with low activity. For the Pd(Ac)H catalyst, the experiments were conducted in the range 20–60 °C. Kinetic experiments were repeated up to four times per catalyst element to monitor the impact of catalyst deactivation. 2.6 Interpretation of kinetic results and mathematical modelling In the loop reactor, only a part of the liquid is in direct contact with the catalyst, while the rest was continuously recirculating without being catalytically converted. At a given time, only a fraction V L,cat /V L ,tot of the fluid was converted, which leads to a time delay compared to a classical batch reactor, where the entire liquid volume interacts with the catalyst simultaneously. If the conversion per pass is very low, the reactant concentrations throughout the loop remain nearly uniform, allowing the use of a classical stirred tank reactor model to describe the experimental data. However, more advanced reactor models would be required if concentration gradients arise in the loop system. Under the assumption of a low conversion per pass, the consumption of hydrogen peroxide can be written as for the classical batch reactor system (1) d n H 2 O 2 d t = − r ρ B w Pd V L where r is the reaction rate per mass of palladium (mol k g Pd − 1 s−1), ρ B is the catalyst bulk density, i.e., the ratio between catalyst mass and volume of the liquid phase, w Pd is the palladium content and V L is the volume of the liquid phase. It is anticipated that partial deactivation of the structured catalysts appeared after exposing the palladium nanoparticles to hydrogen peroxide. To describe the deactivation, many empirical models have been proposed in the literature [31,32]. Assuming that the catalyst deactivation does not depend on the reactant concentration and an asymptotic residual activity is approached, the dependence of the rate constant with the time can be written as [31] (2) k app ( T O S ) = k d − ( k d − k 0 ) e − α ⋅ t where k d is the residual rate constant, k 0 is the initial rate constant and α is the deactivation frequency. It is worth noting that the time in Eq.2 represents a cumulative exposure time of the catalyst to the reacting mixture, therefore it has a similar concept as the time on stream (TOS) for continuous reactors. Eq. 1 is valid for a loop reactor only in case of a uniform concentration within the loop system, thus a low reactant conversion per pass. To confirm this assumption, the rate constants obtained using Eq. (1) were compared with a tank-in-series model, in which the packed bed reactor was approximated to N tot perfectly backmixed reactors coupled in series and operating under transient conditions (Fig. 2B). (3) d n H 2 O 2 , j L d t = Q C H 2 O 2 , j − 1 − C H 2 O 2 , j − r j ρ B , j w Pd V j (4) d n H 2 O 2 T d t = Q ( C H 2 O 2 , N t o t − C H 2 O 2 , T ) Eq. (4) represents the mass balance equation governing the mixing tank (T), while Eq. (3) describes the variation of the hydrogen peroxide amount in the loop (L). Three tanks were assumed to simulate the zones before and after the catalyst structure in the bed. Numerical simulations showed that the results are not affected by the number of tanks in these sectors of the loop reactor. One tank was used to model the catalytic zone owing to the very small liquid volume inside the structured bed (V L, cat = 0.68 cm3). First order kinetics was assumed for the catalytic hydrogen peroxide decomposition, and Eq. 2 described the catalyst deactivation. It is worth to highlight that the catalyst bulk density in Eq. 3 refers to the liquid volume contained in the catalyst structure. Therefore, it is higher than the bulk density of a classical stirred tank reactor system (Eq. 1) of a factor V L,tot/V L,cat. In the other sections of the bed, the hydrogen peroxide consumption rate (r j) was set to zero. Blank experiments confirmed negligible uncatalyzed decomposition processes. The initial conditions to solve Eqs. 5 and 6 can be written in a compact form as (5) n 0 , H 2 O 2 j = n 0 , H 2 O 2 , tot V j V L , tot Both the ordinary differential equation of the batch reactor model (Eq. 1) and the system of ordinary differential equations of the tank-in-series model (Eqs. 3 and 4) were solved using MATLAB R2023b software, using the built-in ode15s routine. The solver lsqnonlin was used for nonlinear regression analysis, which utilizes a Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm to find the optimal set of the rate parameters (k d , k 0 and α) that minimizes the sum of squares between the experimental and simulated data. It is worth to mention that the mathematical analysis described above does not directly include internal and external mass transport phenomena. Fluid-solid mass transport limitations and reaction-diffusion mathematical models should in future be implemented for a more rigorous mathematical treatment of the system. However, the classical treatment of intraparticle diffusion and the calculation of effectiveness factor according to the theory proposed by Thiele cannot be applied for chemical reactions producing a gas phase inside the catalyst pores, which reduces the liquid holdup in the pores [33,34]. As the catalyst structures were composed of the same geometry and they were tested under identical fluid dynamic conditions, it is possible to infer that the comparison between different catalyst structures was conducted under the same mass transfer regime. Thus, the obtained apparent rate constants fulfill the scope of the current work, which aims to relate the activity results with the catalyst textural properties. Nonetheless, the Weisz-Prater criterion was used to evaluate the presence of intraparticle diffusion resistance. For the transport in the pores to be negligible, the value of the criterion (Eq. 6) should be substantially lower than 1. (6) C W - P = r obs ρ C R 2 D e C H 2 O 2 To have a conservative criterion, the effective diffusion coefficient (D e) was assumed to be 10 % of the molecular diffusion coefficient of hydrogen peroxide in aqueous medium, which was taken from ref. [33]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 3D printing of the catalyst structures Digital light processing DLP enabled accurate production of the alumina structured elements. (Fig. 1b). After thermal degradation of the organic components, the radial structure shrinkage was 14 %, while the axial shrinkage was 20 % with respect to the set values to the computer aided design (CAD). Thus, the final dimensions of the alumina bodies were 12.83 × 8 mm (d x h). The average size of the alumina walls was 460 μm. The obtained geometrical information for printed structures after shrinking were applied to reproduce digital replicas on nTop software to retrieve important geometrical parameters for the mathematical modelling. For a given structure, the specific surface area was 5000 m−1, while the porosity ε, i.e., the ratio between the empty volume and the total cylindrical volume was 0.65. The liquid volume in the catalytic zone V L,cat was 0.68 cm3, meaning that only 0.45 % of the liquid (150 cm3) was in contact with the catalyst in the loop reactor. The obtained value of V L,cat was used in Eqs. 1, 3 and 4 for the non-linear regression analysis with the batch and the tank-in-series models. The infiltration with colloidal boehmite nanoparticles is an essential post-printing operation to obtain catalyst structures with suitable mechanical strengths [15]. The final alumina structures had the surface area 150 m2 g−1 and the pore volume 0.44 cm3 g−1. In the field of structured catalysis, the relation between mechanical performance and textural properties is of paramount importance. For porous alumina catalyst architectures, infiltration with colloidal boehmite nanoparticles was shown to be a promising method [15,35]. A systematic study on the influence of post-processing treatment on the structure strength and the porosity will be the subject of our future work. 3.2 Comparison between wet impregnation with Pd(Cl)2 and Pd(Ac)2 Fig. 3 provides a schematic overview of the effect of different palladium precursors in the incorporation onto the 3D-printed alumina structures. During wet impregnation using the PdCl₂ precursor, a partial loss of solid alumina particles from the structured body was observed, which was attributed to the low pH necessary to dissolve the precursor palladium chloride in distilled water to form the negatively charged [PdCl₄]²⁻complex. The acidic environment promotes alumina dissolution through interaction with H⁺ ions [36], thus weakening the cohesion between solid particles within the 3D framework and resulting in a material loss from the structure. Therefore, the impregnation was stopped after 4 h to avoid excessive mass loss from the structured supports. Although this dissolution may not be evident when depositing palladium onto alumina powder, it became noticeable in case of shaped bodies due to increased turbidity of the solution. A 10 % weight loss was observed when weighting the structures before the deposition. The ICP measurements revealed that the efficiency of the method was 75 %, thus the actual Pd loading was 1.5 wt%. Tetraamminepalladium sulfate Pd(NH₃)₄SO₄ was also tested to deposit palladium on the alumina surface, using the same method applied for PdCl2. In water, Pd(NH₃)₄SO₄ forms [Pd(NH₃)₄]2+ cations, therefore the solution pH was increased to 10 to negatively charge the alumina surface and promote the electrostatic adsorption. Similarly to PdCl2, severe increase of the solution turbidity was observed. and the deposited palladium content was negligible. Since the alumina support was unstable in both acidic and basic environments, acetone was selected as an organic solvent, along with organometallic palladium precursors that are soluble in non-aqueous media. The use a palladium acetate (Pd(Ac)₂) precursor dissolved in acetone resulted in the complete deposition of palladium species onto the catalyst structures. ICP analysis confirmed complete correspondence between the nominal and the actual Pd content (2 wt%). Moreover, no material loss was observed from the alumina body. The impregnation time was set at 24 h to ensure complete deposition of the palladium precursor. However, palladium adsorption seemed to be completed after only 6 h of deposition. The same method was used applying palladium acetylacetonate Pd(AcAc)2 as the precursor. However, the deposition was not efficient, highlighting the importance of the selected precursor in wet deposition methods. The nature of the palladium precursor has a significant impact on the metal distribution within the catalyst walls. When PdCl₂ was used, palladium exhibited a uniform distribution, whereas an egg-shell distribution was observed with the palladium acetate precursor, as confirmed by both optical microscopy and EDX line scan analysis. To enhance the color contrast, the comparison was shown after metal reduction in hydrogen atmosphere, but the egg-shell distribution was already observed after impregnation. Many parameters can affect the distribution of a metal within the support framework such as choice of the precursor, pH, type of solvent, impregnation time and drying conditions [37,38] Herein, the combination of the selected solvent and the type of precursor was the crucial factor in determining the location of palladium in the alumina walls. In acidic water, PdCl2 exists in tetracoordinated form with chloride ions in [PdCl₄]²⁻ complexes, which had evidently a weaker interaction with the support, enabling equilibration in the pores as well as a uniform distribution [38]. A more complex issue is the speciation of Pd(Ac)2 in acetone solvents, which can form dimers or trimers depending on the precursor concentration [39]. The application of Pd(Ac)2 as the precursor for Pd/Al2O3 catalysts has been scarcely studied in the available literature. To the best of our knowledge, only Kinnunen et al. [40] have conducted a systematic investigation on the use of Pd(Ac)₂ to synthetize alumina-supported palladium catalysts. Their findings indicated that the acidity of alumina increases by almost 50 % when dispersed in acetone, which might explain the enhanced interactions between the alumina surface and the acetate ligands of Pd(Ac)₂ in acetone. Stronger interactions enhanced adsorption of the precursor, preventing it to diffuse towards the inner part of the catalyst wall. Overall, this experimental experience provides a straightforward and reproducible method to prepare Pd/Al2O3 with an egg-shell metal distribution. Moreover, the density of metal clusters is reduced when the palladium precursor is spread uniformly in the catalyst walls. Consequently, the size of the metal nanoparticles was smaller in case of the catalysts prepared from the PdCl2 precursor ( Fig. 4). The comparison was conducted on the catalysts reduced with H2 in the gas phase. Interestingly, the utilization of various reducing agents led to a different distribution of the palladium nanoparticles. Despite the similar average size, a broader distribution was observed when reducing PdO nanoparticles with an aqueous solution of NaBH4 (Fig. 4c). On the contrary, smaller nanoparticles were formed as NaBH4 was applied on the palladium nanoparticles prereduced with H2 (Fig. 4d). It is well established that Pd nanoparticles catalyze the oxidation of NaBH4. The chemical reduction generates H2 in situ and might produce local variations of the solution pH [41]. The surface charge of both Pd and Al2O3 in the solution environment might lead to nanoparticle reconstruction in the NaBH4 solution environment. To understand the kinetics of such complex phenomenon, a more systematic study on the topic is required. However, it goes beyond the scope of the current work. Nonetheless, the variation of the nanoparticle size showed in Fig. 4 anticipates remarkable differences in the activity and stability of the palladium nanoparticles in the decomposition of H2O2. 3.3 Kinetic experiments The results of hydrogen peroxide decomposition experiments using the 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ structures with PdCl₂ as the palladium source are summarized in Fig. 5. Enhanced performance was observed when the palladium nanoparticles were in the reduced state, confirming that metallic palladium exhibits higher activity in the H2O2 decomposition. Similar findings have been reported by Choudhary et al. on the influence of the Pd oxidation state in Pd/Al2O3 catalysts [26]. For both catalysts, a decline of the conversion was observed after consecutive experiments under identical operating conditions (Figs. 5a and 5b). The ICP analysis indicated the absence of palladium in the reaction mixture, highlighting that no leaching had taken place. Moreover, the TEM micrographs revealed similar particle size distributions for fresh and spent catalysts. Therefore, the observed deactivation was ascribed to changes in the palladium speciation on the catalyst support, particularly the formation of PdO species which are difficult to reduce. The characterization results supporting this hypothesis are presented in the section 3.4. In case of the Pd(Cl)H catalyst, the deactivation occurred after the first experiment, after which the conversion profile remained unchanged. The summary of the kinetic experiments for the Pd(Ac)H catalyst at different reaction temperatures is provided in Fig. 6. Improved performance is observed when using the Pd(Ac)2 precursor (Fig. 6c) compared to PdCl2 (Fig. 5b) under identical reaction conditions. At first glance, a better activity could be attributed to a more efficient deposition method, which enabled a complete deposition of the palladium precursor onto the structured alumina support, resulting in a higher total palladium loading. However, notable differences were evident when comparing the performance in terms of the apparent rate constant ( Table 2), which is not dependent on the mass of palladium. A twofold increase of the rate constant was observed for the fresh Pd(Ac)H catalyst compared to Pd(Cl)H due to the confinement of the active phase on the outer catalyst shell, evidently suppressing the intraparticle diffusion limitations. The calculated value of the Weisz-Prater criterion was about 20 for the Pd(Cl)H catalyst, indicating that the reaction was heavily retarded by intraparticle diffusion resistance. In case of the Pd(Ac)H catalyst, the palladium is confined in a 200 μm catalytic layer, thus diminishing the diffusional length and the value of the Weisz-Prater criterion, which was estimated to be 10 according to Eq. 6. The main difference in the performance of the Pd(Ac)H and Pd(Cl)H catalysts lies in the distribution of the active phase within the catalyst walls, which reduced intraparticle diffusion limitations in case of Pd(Ac)H egg-shell catalyst. Given the efficiency of the deposition method and the improved performance, further investigations on the catalyst regeneration and mitigation of deactivation were performed with the catalysts prepared from Pd(Ac)2. Catalyst regeneration and recyclability experiments were conducted by withdrawing the structured elements from the loop reactor and drying them prior to the reduction procedure. Visual inspections confirmed the integrity of the catalysts after the reaction cycles. Moreover, the weight of the catalyst remained unchanged, confirming that the loss of fines was negligible. These observations confirmed the suitable strength of the material for the low-temperature H2O2 decomposition. When trying to regenerate the catalyst by reducing it in hydrogen atmosphere at 350 °C, the catalytic activity was marginally recovered ( Fig. 7a), confirming that the formed PdO species are hardly reducible and cannot be converted back to the same metallic Pd by applying the same reduction method as for the fresh catalyst. Conversely, complete regeneration was achieved using NaBH4, which is a strong reducing agent soluble in water (Fig. 7b). Furthermore, the deactivation was clearly mitigated, unveiling the impact of different reducing agents on the stability of the metallic palladium nanoparticles in an oxidizing environment. Fig. 8 shows the activity profiles of catalysts reduced with different techniques. The utilization of NaBH4 as the sole reducing agent minimized deactivation (Fig. 8a), while the best catalytic activity was obtained when treating the nanoparticles with both hydrogen and NaBH4 (Fig. 8b). The kinetic experiments highlighted the crucial importance of the reduction method on both the initial performance and the resilience against oxidation, thus an in-depth analysis of the palladium nanoparticle properties, particularly the oxidation state and reducibility, was required. 3.4 Bridging the results of kinetic experiments, mathematical modelling and characterization of the catalyst deactivation phenomena Both the simplified batch model and the tank-in-series model gave a successful description of the conversion profiles and catalyst deactivation in the loop reactor, with a coefficient of determination R2 > 0.98 for all the structured bodies. The simulation results are provided in Figs. 5–8. The parity plot comparing the experimental and simulation results displayed in Fig. 9 demonstrates that both the batch and the tank-in-series models described the experimental data within a 10 % margin. Table 2 reports the apparent rate constant and deactivation coefficients obtained via non-linear regression analysis. The estimated parameters with the batch (Table 2) and the tank-in-series model were nearly identical, with small differences in the confidence intervals, thus proving the validity of the assumption of a low conversion per pass in the loop reactor. Apparent rate constants for palladium-supported catalysts in powder form have been reported in the range of 0.001–0.08 m³ ·kg⁻¹ ·s⁻1 [26,42,43]. The values presented in Table 2 fall within the lower part of this range. When employing 3D-printed structural elements in a loop reactor, the mass transfer regime differs significantly from that of conventional batch experiments using powdered catalysts under vigorous stirring. As a result, smaller catalyst particles in batch systems may exhibit higher apparent rate constants. However, fine particles are unsuitable for use in H₂O₂ decomposition thrusters due to the high pressure drop they would introduce in the catalytic chamber. Previous investigations on hydrogen peroxide decomposition using 3D-printed structured elements have reported apparent rate constants in the range of 10⁻⁵ to 10⁻⁶ m³ ·kg⁻¹ ·s⁻¹ [22], which are orders of magnitude lower compared to the values shown in Table 2, highlighting the effectiveness of the proposed method for fabricating 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ catalysts. For the Pd(Ac)2 catalyst, it was shown that complete regeneration is possible exposing the catalyst surface to the strong reducing agent NaBH4, suggesting that the principal cause of deactivation is the change of the oxidation state of the palladium nanoparticles when exposed to liquid hydrogen peroxide, which is a strong oxidation agent. Therefore, the oxidation states of the tested catalysts were monitored with TPR and XPS. The total palladium content was 189 μmol g−1 for catalysts prepared with Pd(Ac)2 and 147 μmol g−1 when Pd(Cl)2 was applied. Due to the low palladium loading and low signal intensity, it was not possible to discriminate between the different oxides Pd(II) and Pd(IV) with XPS analysis. Indeed, the deconvolution of the XPS spectra did not improve the fitting when using three peaks for the signal interpretation. Therefore, the XPS analysis was used to determine the ratio between the metallic species, Pd(0), and oxidized palladium, Pd(II). The results are reported in Fig. 10 and Table 3. A clear shift from Pd(II) to Pd(0) is observed when reducing the catalytic material with hydrogen. The comparison between fresh and spent Pd(Cl)H confirmed partial oxidation of palladium during the reaction, which is the principal cause of catalyst deactivation. When NaBH4 was applied as the reducing agent, surface oxidation was observed also in the fresh catalysts, probably because of the creation of a passivated oxide layer when exposing that catalyst to water. A small increase in the Pd(II)/Pd(0) ratio was observed in the spent catalyst. Therefore, it is possible to infer that the metallic palladium species are partially oxidized during the hydrogen peroxide decomposition process. For the non-reduced Pd(Cl)O catalyst, some deactivation was observed (Fig. 5a), so it is possible to conclude that the nature of the formed oxides is different when the catalyst is exposed to hydrogen peroxide. For the reduced materials, the palladium oxidation is not complete under the investigated experimental conditions and the observed residual activity is associated with a mixture of Pdn+ and Pd0. Concerning the relatively large size of the palladium clusters, the Pd(II) content in the catalytic materials is mainly related to the outer palladium surface and not to the bulk palladium. Regarding the TPR experiments, the obtained thermograms and relative hydrogen uptakes are summarized in Fig. 11 and Table 3, respectively. All the catalysts revealed a sharp negative peak at T = 60°C, which is related to the desorption of hydrogen from β-PdH species [44]. For the non-pre-reduced catalyst Pd(Cl)O, a very small peak at T = 300 °C is observed, suggesting that the major part of the palladium species is already reduced at room temperature during the stabilization of the TC detector. Many examples reported in literature displayed reduction peaks at T < 20 °C [45–47], which requires a specific instrumentation and cooling units to be detected. In case of reduced catalysts in the fresh state, Pd(Cl)H and Pd(Ac)H, no peaks were observed. On the contrary, the spent catalysts revealed broad reduction peaks at T = 400°C, proving that hard-to-reduce palladium oxides are formed during the hydrogen peroxide decomposition. High temperature reduction peaks for Pd/Al2O3 catalyst materials in the absence of any promotors have been scarcely reported in the existing literature. Among the first, Lieske and Voltaire attributed those peaks to the formation of stable palladium oxide surface complexes [PdO]sc [48], which have a strong interaction with the support. Their results were obtained exposing Pd/Al2O3 at high temperatures (600 and 900 °C) under oxygen atmosphere. Given the obtained thermograms for spent catalysts in this work, a similar oxidation behavior is presumed when exposing palladium nanoparticles to hydrogen peroxide in the liquid phase. The surface complexes are expected to be formed at the palladium-alumina interphase, resulting in strong interactions with the support material. This conclusion might be in contrast with the relatively large sizes of the palladium clusters observed in TEM micrographs. However, Ivanova et al. [49] have shown that a thin aluminate layer on palladium nanoparticles supported on alumina is formed when the material is treated at temperatures exceeding 550 °C, which is the case of all the tested samples prior to their reduction in this work. Therefore, even bigger palladium nanoparticles can exhibit strong interactions with the alumina support, justifying the high reduction temperatures even for large palladium clusters. Calculation of the hydrogen uptake from the integration of the reduction peaks (Table 3) enabled the quantification of the H/Pd ratio for the spent catalysts. The calculations revealed that in some cases this ratio is about 1 or higher. The calculation was performed using the total palladium content. However, the XPS analysis confirmed the coexistence of Pd(II) and Pd(0) in the spent materials, implying that the deactivation process involves the formation of higher palladium oxides PdOx, with x > 1. An excess in the hydrogen uptake with respect to stoichiometric PdO has also been observed by Sandova and Gigola [50], who attributed the excess of the oxygen consumption to oxygen-rich palladium species originated on the metal-support interphase. The presence of this kind of species was suggested initially from by Lesage-Rosenberg et al. [51], who applied EXAFS measurements to show the presence of multiple oxygen atoms, up to six, occupying aluminum-vacant sites in the proximity of palladium nanoparticles. Palladium species at higher oxidation state Pd(IV) can be stabilized on supports like Al2O3 and SnO3 [52,53]. Concerning the structure-activity relationships, it was previously explained that the metal distribution within the catalyst walls is the main reason for improved apparent rate constants in case of the catalysts prepared from the acetate precursor. For the Pd(Ac) catalysts, a correlation between the average particle size (Table 3) and the initial activity k 0 (Table 2) is observed. However, the final activity parameter k d is mainly dictated by the reduction method. Indeed, it was observed that palladium reduced with NaBH4, Pd(Ac)B, exhibited the highest residual activity. A similar residual activity was observed when treating spent palladium nanoparticles (Pd(Ac)HSB) with NaBH4. When treating the material (Pd(Ac)HB) before the catalytic experiment, the already reduced particles with NaBH4, the resulting nanoparticles were smaller, giving a higher initial activity, but the catalyst deactivated to a higher extent. Regarding the catalyst pretreated with hydrogen (Pd(Ac)HX), a correlation between the final hydrogen uptake and the residual activity k d was observed, unveiling a different resistance to overoxidation given by the reduction method. An exception was observed for the Pd(Ac)B catalyst, which exhibited two distinct reduction peaks at 200°C and 400 °C and the highest hydrogen uptake, nonetheless the best residual activity. This peculiar behavior can be attributed to a different shapes of the formed nanoparticles when reduced directly with NaBH4. In fact, two different forms of palladium nanoparticles in Pd(Ac)B were observed: quasi-cubic particles with sharp edges and quasi-spherical ones ( Fig. 12a). For the other catalysts, only quasi-spherical nanoparticles were visible (Fig. 12b). Different particle geometries might be the reason for different reduction peaks as well as different residual activities. The main difference between various reducing agents lies in the reduction kinetics and surface charge of palladium nanoparticles. The treatment of palladium oxides with NaBH4 yields to an increase of the solution pH during the chemical reduction, thus modifying the surface charge of the palladium nanoparticles, which affects their final state after the reduction [53]. It can be concluded that this analysis unveiled the crucial importance of the reduction method on both the stability and durability of palladium nanoparticles. 4 Conclusions and future perspectives DLP 3D printing was used to fabricate structured alumina supports with high geometrical resolution. Palladium nanoparticles were deposited using various wet impregnation methods and precursors, namely Pd(Cl)₂ and Pd(Ac)₂. Complete adsorption of Pd(Ac)₂ was achieved, leading to an egg-shell distribution of palladium, while the use Pd(Cl)₂ resulted in a more homogeneous palladium distribution. The obtained catalysts were benchmarked in the hydrogen peroxide decomposition in a closed loop-reactor system. Metallic palladium was more active than the respective oxides. However, partial catalyst deactivation occurred because of the formation of surface palladium oxides. By applying different reduction methods, deactivation effects can be mitigated. The application of NaBH4 improved the resistance to overoxidation. The experimental data were successfully described using both the tank-in-series model for the loop reactor and the simpler batch reactor model. Structure-activity relationships were assessed by combining the characterization and mathematical modelling results. This work formed a solid preliminary background for the future development of monopropellant thrusters operated with a 3D printed catalytic materials. Dramatic improvement in the thruster performance is expected because of tunable geometry to control the transport phenomena and the flow pattern. In future, new alternatives should be explored to make the catalytic materials more resistant to overoxidation e.g., applying new reduction methods as well as stability promoters. The success of the future application of this technology will require extensive collaboration efforts between chemists, chemical engineers, and aerospace engineers CRediT authorship contribution statement Luca Mastroianni: Writing – review & editing, Writing – original draft, Visualization, Validation, Supervision, Software, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Design, fabrication, and evaluation of the performance of 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ catalysts for the low-temperature catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide was investigated. Catalyst supports were manufactured using a digital light processing (DLP) 3D printing technique, followed by post-printing infiltration with colloidal boehmite to enhance the mechanical strength of the supports. Wet impregnation methods using PdCl₂ and Pd(Ac)₂ as the palladium precursors were employed to deposit metal nanoparticles onto the structured alumina supports. For the most effective deposition route, various strategies, using either molecular hydrogen or sodium borohydride as the reducing agent, were applied to assess their influence on the catalytic activity. The decomposition experiments were carried out in a closed-loop batch reactor system. Apparent rate constants and deactivation coefficients were estimated using simplified batch and tank-in-series reactor models. Catalyst durability was further investigated with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to assess the oxidation states of the palladium nanoparticle surface, and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) to evaluate the reducibility of the palladium oxides. Structure–activity relationships were established by correlating kinetic parameters with hydrogen uptake data and average nanoparticle size obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The results demonstrated the critical impact of the precursor and the reduction methods on both the initial activity and the resistance against deactivation. This work provides a robust foundation for the further development of 3D-printed Pd/Al₂O₃ catalysts, offering a promising pathway to improve the efficiency of green propulsion systems for small satellites utilizing hydrogen peroxide as a propellant.
